channel.title: A Hugo website
channel.description: Recent content on A Hugo website

item.title: Seriation
item.description: What is seriation? The verb seriate denotes the arrangement of items in a sequence according to a prescribed criterion. Seriation is a standard method of dating in archeology, i.e. assemblages or artifacts from numerous sites in the same culture are placed in chronological order. In psychology, seriation is part of Piaget’s theory of cognitive development: during the Concrete Operational Stage of development a child develops the ability to sort objects or situations according to their characteristic.

item.title: Covid Cases and Deaths in NY city zip code areas
item.description: Data for NYC The New York City Department of Health publishes its coronavirus data on github. The repository includes detailed information on the data sets and the definitions of the variables within the data. Our interest is in the zip code data: how virulent is the virus within our neighborhood? The files “data-by-modzcta.csv” contain data on cases and deaths by cumulative count and rate, population, percentage of people tested positive and the number of people tested for each modified ZIP code tabulation area (ZCTA).

item.title: Training for knowledge workers
item.description: Tyler Cowen poses the question: “What is it you do to train that is comparable to a pianist practicing scales?” and references the blog post by David Perell Learn like an athlete.

item.title: Setting up myblog
item.description: After much trial-and-error, I found that the following steps worked best for me on a Windows machine once my github account had been set up: Run through Chapters 1 - 14 of happygitwithr.com and ensure that RStudio can connect to your github account. Implement chapter 15 of happygitwithr.com. Chapter 15 shows you how to set up a github folder for your site, clone it and open the R project for the site in the cloned directory.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: Owen Beelders is a quant in New York city. Owen was born and raised in South Africa and completed his B.Sc.(Economics, Statistics), B.Sc.(Hons) (Statistics) and M.A.(Economics) at the University of Cape Town. He spent two years in graduate studies at Simon Fraser before completing his PhD at the University of Rochester. Owen spent five years in Academia in the Department of Economics at Emory University and then he moved to Industry.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
